# Huntington Ingalls Industries, Inc. (HII) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

Huntington Ingalls Industries, Inc. (HII) is the largest military shipbuilding company in the United States and designs, builds, overhauls, and repairs military ships in the United States. HII was formed on 31 March 2011, as a divestiture from Northrop Grumman, and comprises three divisions: Newport News Shipbuilding in Virginia, Ingalls Shipbuilding in Mississippi, and Mission Technologies.

Newport News Shipbuilding is the sole designer, builder, and refueler of U.S. Navy nuclear-powered aircraft carriers and one of two providers of nuclear-powered submarines. Ingalls Shipbuilding constructs amphibious assault ships, amphibious transport dock ships, and guided missile destroyers. The creation and subsequent aggressive expansion of the Technical Solutions division (now Mission Technologies), particularly through acquisitions like Camber, Novetta ISR group, and Alion, fundamentally shifted HII's business mix. This reduced reliance on large-platform shipbuilding cycles and tapped into faster-growing, higher-margin technology and service markets.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

**Shipbuilding:**
- As the nation's sole designer-builder of nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, HII is currently designing and building the next-generation of aircraft carriers – the Gerald R. Ford class
- HII's Newport News Shipbuilding is one of only two U.S. shipyards capable of designing and building nuclear-powered submarines. Under an innovative agreement, Newport News Shipbuilding is producing these submarines as part of a teaming agreement with General Dynamics Electric Boat
- HII builds LPD 17 San Antonio and LHA America classes of amphibious warships. Designed and built for survivability and flexibility, U.S. Navy amphibious warships are unique combat warships. HII's Ingalls Shipbuilding is building the entire San Antonio class of ships

**Mission Technologies:**
- Provides C5ISR systems and operations; application of artificial intelligence and machine learning to battlefield decisions; defensive and offensive cyberspace strategies and electronic warfare; uncrewed autonomous systems; live, virtual, and constructive solutions; and fleet sustainment; and critical nuclear operations
- HII creates advanced unmanned solutions for defense, marine research and commercial applications. Serving customers in more than 30 countries, HII provides design, autonomy, manufacturing, testing, operations and sustainment of unmanned systems, including unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs) and unmanned surface vessels (USVs). The company's REMUS UUVs - world-leading, untethered, autonomous marine robots - carry advanced sensors and payloads to collect valuable data for a variety of applications

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

**Trump-Class Battleships:**
Huntington Ingalls Industries, Inc. stands to benefit from renewed U.S. naval investment, especially amid rising tensions with China and proposed "Trump-class" battleships. Upgrading the aging U.S. Navy is a bipartisan priority, with HII positioned as the nation's leading defense shipbuilder and likely recipient of major contracts. Military analysts at the venerable Janes publication estimate the first Trump-class battleship will cost as much as [an] aircraft carrier," which suggests a price tag of perhaps $14 billion.

**Small Surface Combatants:**
HII announced Friday that its Ingalls Shipbuilding division has been awarded a contract by the U.S. Navy to design and build the future small surface combatant (SSC) ship, based on the company's Legend-class national security cutter design.

**ROMULUS Unmanned Surface Vessel:**
HII announced the ROMULUS unmanned surface vessel prototype reached 30% completion at Breaux Brothers shipyard on Dec 11, 2025 and remains on schedule for sea trials in Q4 2026. ROMULUS is a modular, AI‑enabled USV family built around HII's Odyssey Autonomous Control System, with reported speeds over 25 knots and a range of 2,500 nautical miles.

## 5. Growth Strategy

**Distributed Shipbuilding:**
HII's acquisition of a manufacturing facility in Charleston, South Carolina, and its distributed shipbuilding model aim to streamline production for submarines and aircraft carriers, addressing long-standing bottlenecks in the defense industrial base. HII highlighted efforts to increase shipbuilding throughput: more than 40 ships are in active construction or modernization across Ingalls and NNS; the company partnered with 23 shipyards and fabricators and international manufacturers to expand capacity. The agreement authorizes Babcock to build complex submarine assemblies at its Rosyth, Scotland facility for Virginia-class Block VI fast-attack submarines.

**Operational Improvements:**
HII is expecting to achieve a 15% throughput improvement for fiscal 2025, with enhancement efforts accelerating throughput throughout the year. The company has hired 4,600 shipbuilders this year and has seen an improvement in retention rates at both shipyards. There has also been a growth in experienced hires following the wage investment this year, as well as increased hiring from regional workforce development pipelines. Moreover, the company is expanding its industrial base through its distributed shipbuilding strategy.

**Technology Integration:**
Entered into a strategic partnership with C3 AI to expand our use of digital technologies and apply artificial intelligence to accelerate shipbuilding throughput.

On October 30, the company reported financial results for the third quarter of fiscal 2025, with record third quarter sales of $3.2 billion, up 16.1% year-over-year, driven by strong growth across the Ingalls Shipbuilding, Newport News Shipbuilding, and Mission Technologies divisions. Diluted earnings per share came in at $3.68, up nearly 44% from the prior year's quarter, and beating estimates of $3.29 per share. Segment operating income stood at $179 million, with a margin of 5.6%.

**Backlog & Contract Awards:**
- In 2023, HII received $5.4 billion in new contract awards, resulting in a backlog of approximately $49 billion
- HII secured $2 billion in new contract awards during the recent quarter, increasing its total backlog to $55.7 billion as of September 30, 2025
- The company's crown jewel is its record-breaking backlog, which stood at $55.7 billion as of late 2025. This provides roughly five years of revenue visibility, an enviable position in any industry

**Cash Flow:**
While free cash flow (FCF) was pressured in early 2024 due to heavy capital expenditures in the shipyards, 2025 saw a recovery, with FCF guidance for the year landing between $550 million and $650 million.

## 8. Headwinds & Tailwinds

**Tailwinds:**
- The Department of Defense's focus on rebuilding domestic industrial capacity and accelerating procurement timelines has directly benefited HII
- President Trump called for the nation's defense spending to rise to $1.5 trillion, a substantial jump of over 50% from the $850 billion budget for fiscal 2025
- The market for military shipbuilding and submarines is growing demand with the evolving threats and geopolitical instability, increasing defence budgets, and the need for advanced naval capabilities
- Geopolitically, the escalating tensions in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait act as a constant catalyst for naval readiness spending

**Headwinds:**
- On October 10, 2024, the People's Republic of China announced sanctions on three U.S. military-industrial companies and 10 Americans, including Huntington Ingalls Industries and its president and CEO Christopher D. Kastner, for participating in arms sales to Taiwan
- Key challenges include potential supply chain disruptions, ongoing wage negotiations at Newport News and Ingalls, and competition in unmanned systems
- Despite these achievements, the company faces challenges such as maintaining a robust maritime supply chain and managing costs effectively to support higher shipbuilding throughput
- HII is entirely dependent on the U.S. defense budget (NDAA). While bipartisan support for naval spending remains strong, any significant shift in domestic fiscal policy could impact procurement rates

## 9. Market Shares

**Naval Shipbuilding Leadership:**
The company holding the most market share in the Global Military Shipbuilding & Submarines industry is General Dynamics Corporation, however Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) is the largest military shipbuilder in the U.S., focusing on nuclear-powered submarines and a variety of naval surface ships through its Newport News Shipbuilding and Ingalls Shipbuilding divisions.

**Market Position:**
- While HII's Newport News Shipbuilding is the sole provider of nuclear-powered aircraft carriers for the U.S. Navy, it shares the nuclear submarine market with General Dynamics Electric Boat
- These contracts, coupled with a 6.37% market share in the Ship & Boat Building Industry, position HII to outperform peers as the Navy prioritizes multi-domain operations and AI-driven systems

## 10. Comparison to Competitors

**Primary Competitors:**
In the naval shipbuilding sector, HII's primary competitor is General Dynamics (GD), particularly through its Electric Boat division. The two companies actually collaborate on the Virginia-class submarine program, with each building different sections of the vessels, though they compete for prime contractor status on various naval programs. In the non-nuclear shipbuilding segment, HII's Ingalls Shipbuilding competes with several shipyards including Austal USA, Fincantieri Marinette Marine, and Bath Iron Works (a division of General Dynamics).

**Competitive Advantages:**
- HII's moat is wide and deep: there are huge switching costs, decades of nuclear know-how, and one-of-a-kind US shipyards
- HII's dominance in nuclear-powered shipbuilding—exclusive to aircraft carriers, submarines, and Coast Guard National Security Cutters—provides a structural moat against competitors like General Dynamics and BAE Systems
- HII's differentiation lies in digital shipbuilding technologies, such as 3D model-based design for Virginia-class submarines, reducing construction rework by 30% compared to General Dynamics' legacy methods

## 11. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

**Strategic Partnerships:**
HII and Babcock International Group signed a contract on Dec. 9, 2025 to expand their strategic partnership supporting Virginia-class submarine construction at HII's Newport News Shipbuilding. The agreement authorizes Babcock to build complex submarine assemblies at its Rosyth, Scotland facility for Virginia-class Block VI fast-attack submarines.

Signed MOU with HD Hyundai Heavy Industries to enhance technological innovation in the sector.

**Recent Acquisitions:**
This diversification accelerated with several strategic acquisitions, including Camber Corporation (2016), Fulcrum IT Services (2019), Hydroid (2020), and Alion Science and Technology (2021).

**Facility Expansions:**
HII marked one year of Newport News Shipbuilding Charleston Operations in Goose Creek, S.C., after an asset acquisition closing in January 2025. The site delivered its first unit within the first 40 days as NNS Charleston Operations and has exceeded 2025 production targets while ramping submarine and carrier work.

**Facility & International Expansion:**

The site will provide operational, technical and logistics support, expand sustainment and training for U.K. and European partners, prepare for deployment of ROMULUS unmanned surface vessels.

Key investment highlights include HII's exclusive capabilities in nuclear-powered carrier construction, aggressive expansion into technology services through strategic acquisitions, and strong positioning in emerging defense markets like unmanned autonomous systems. The company is poised to benefit from increasing defense budgets, geopolitical tensions, and proposed naval modernization plans. Significant recent developments include partnerships with international defense firms, expansion of manufacturing facilities, and development of advanced AI-enabled unmanned surface vessels.

The AI investment rating is 8.2/10 (Strong Buy), with a fair value estimate of $450-475, driven by its unique market position and robust government contract pipeline.
